content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION
7 November 1956
Ref: C. L. 28. 1956
Sir,
I have the honour to refer to steps recently taken towards defining more clearly than hitherto, and towards co-ordinating the functions and activities of the International Centres for studies on enteric bacteria, with special reference to their relationships with national laboratories concerned with work of a similar nature.
The International Centres in question are (a) the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark, (b) the International : Shigella Centre, Atlanta, USA, and (c) the International Shigella Centre, London, England. These Centres, by arrangement with the World Health Organization, are in a position to assist Member States of WHO in the matter of laboratory investigations on salmonella, escherichia and shigella micro- organisms, among which are potent causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, food poisoning, infantile diarrhoea and dysentery.
In order to assist me in examining and defining precisely the functions which the International Centres can fulfil, and the exact way in which the laboratories of Member States may benefit by their activities, I invited the directors of the Centres, together with an expert nominated for the purpose by the International Association of Microbiological Societies, to meet as a Consultant Group on 19 to 24 September 1955. This was mentioned in my Annual Report for 1955 (Off. Rec. Wid With Org. 67, pp. xi and 45), and a detailed account of the position studied by the Group, and of their recommendations, is appended herewith as an Annex to this letter. The Annex can be regarded as:
(a) a comprehensive review of the historical circumstances which led to the establishment of the International Centres by WHO;
(b) a full analysis of the functions of the International Centres and of their functional relationships with WHO, with the International Association of Microbiological Societies, and with National Salmonella Centres and National Shigella Centres;
( c) a detailed technical statement of the services which the Inter- national Centres provide to officially designated National Centres; and
(d) a body of suggestions which might be useful for the guidance of national health administrations contemplating the selection and designation of a laboratory as their National Salmonella Centre or National Shigella Centre.
The Director Department of Health Administration Ministry of Interior Taipeh Taiwan Repubbic of China
cc: Dr. J. Heng Liu, Director, China Office ABMAC, Taipeh Dr. C. H. Yen, Department of Health, Taipeh Dr. C. T. Loo, Deputy Director-General, Taipeh
國史饭 Academia Historica
ENCL: Detailed account
68

衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
WORLD HEALTH
ORGANIZATION
7 November 1956
Sir,
I have the honour to refer to steps recently taken towards defining
more clearly than hitherto, and towards co-ordinating the functions and
activities of the International Centres for studies on enteric bacteria,
with special reference to their relationships with national laboratories
concerned with work of a similar nature.
The International Centres in question are (a) the International
Salmonella and Escherichia Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark, (b) the International
: Shigella Centre, Atlanta, USA, and (c) the International Shigella Centre,
London, England. These Centres, by arrangement with the World Health
Organization, are in a position to assist Member States of WHO in the matter
of laboratory investigations on salmonella, escherichia and shigella micro-
organisms, among which are potent causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid
fevers, food poisoning, infantile diarrhoea and dysentery.
In order to assist me in examining and defining precisely the functions
which the International Centres can fulfil, and the exact way in which the
laboratories of Member States may benefit by their activities, I invited the
directors of the Centres, together with an expert nominated for the purpose
by the International Association of Microbiological Societies, to meet as a

Report for 1955 (Off. Rec. Wid With Org. 67, pp. xi and 45), and a detailed
account of the position studied by the Group, and of their recommendations,
is appended herewith as an Annex to this letter. The Annex can be regarded as:
(a) a comprehensive review of the historical circumstances which led
to the establishment of the International Centres by WHO;
(b) a full analysis of the functions of the International Centres
and of their functional relationships with WHO, with the International
Association of Microbiological Societies, and with National Salmonella
Centres and National Shigella Centres;
( c) a detailed technical statement of the services which the Inter-
national Centres provide to officially designated National Centres;
and
(d) a body of suggestions which might be useful for the guidance of
national health administrations contemplating the selection and
designation of a laboratory as their National Salmonella Centre or
National Shigella Centre.
The Director
Department of Health Administration
Ministry of Interior
Taipeh
Taiwan
Repubbic of China
cc: Dr. J. Heng Liu, Director, China Office ABMAC, Taipeh
Dr. C. H. Yen, Department of Health, Taipeh
Dr. C. T. Loo, Deputy Director-General, Taipeh
國史饭
Academia Historica
ENCL: Detailed account

paragraphs.content: 衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等

I have the honour to refer to steps recently taken towards defining more clearly than hitherto, and towards co-ordinating the functions and activities of the International Centres for studies on enteric bacteria, with special reference to their relationships with national laboratories concerned with work of a similar nature.

The International Centres in question are (a) the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark, (b) the International : Shigella Centre, Atlanta, USA, and (c) the International Shigella Centre, London, England. These Centres, by arrangement with the World Health Organization, are in a position to assist Member States of WHO in the matter of laboratory investigations on salmonella, escherichia and shigella micro- organisms, among which are potent causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, food poisoning, infantile diarrhoea and dysentery.

In order to assist me in examining and defining precisely the functions which the International Centres can fulfil, and the exact way in which the laboratories of Member States may benefit by their activities, I invited the directors of the Centres, together with an expert nominated for the purpose by the International Association of Microbiological Societies, to meet as a Consultant Group on 19 to 24 September 1955. This was mentioned in my Annual Report for 1955 (Off. Rec. Wid With Org. 67, pp. xi and 45), and a detailed account of the position studied by the Group, and of their recommendations, is appended herewith as an Annex to this letter. The Annex can be regarded as:
(a) a comprehensive review of the historical circumstances which led to the establishment of the International Centres by WHO;

(b) a full analysis of the functions of the International Centres and of their functional relationships with WHO, with the International Association of Microbiological Societies, and with National Salmonella Centres and National Shigella Centres;
( c) a detailed technical statement of the services which the Inter- national Centres provide to officially designated National Centres; and

(d) a body of suggestions which might be useful for the guidance of national health administrations contemplating the selection and designation of a laboratory as their National Salmonella Centre or National Shigella Centre.
The Director Department of Health Administration Ministry of Interior Taipeh Taiwan Repubbic of China
cc: Dr. J. Heng Liu, Director, China Office ABMAC, Taipeh Dr. C. H. Yen, Department of Health, Taipeh Dr. C. T. Loo, Deputy Director-General, Taipeh
